qas.question: Obesity can cause resistance to which hormone?
In the so called vicious cycle, what aggravates obesity to continue the cycle?
A characteristic of the cycle other than fat storage is a continuously high stimulation of what?
What function do insulin and leptin normally provide in the body?
What effect does insulin/leptin resistance have on the function of insulin/leptin?

context: Obesity can unfavourably alter hormonal and metabolic status via resistance to the hormone <a0_0>leptin<a0_0/>, and a vicious cycle may occur in which <a1_0>insulin/leptin resistance<a1_0/> and obesity aggravate one another. The vicious cycle is putatively fuelled by continuously high insulin/leptin stimulation and fat storage, as a result of high intake of strongly <a2_0>insulin/leptin<a2_0/> stimulating foods and energy. Both insulin and leptin normally function as <a3_0>satiety signals to the hypothalamus<a3_0/> in the brain; however, insulin/leptin resistance may <a4_0>reduce this signal<a4_0/> and therefore allow continued overfeeding despite large body fat stores. In addition, reduced leptin signalling to the brain may reduce leptin's normal effect to maintain an appropriately high metabolic rate.
